PrimEcoSys: Temperate Pacific Tidal Salt and Brackish Marsh
Temperate Pacific Tidal Salt and Brackish Marsh

habitat_description:
Thalasseus elegans has shifted its breeding range northward into the U.S. only during the past century (Grinnell, 1919; Monroe, 1955; Schaffner, 1986; Burness et al., 1999). It is known to breed at only three particular sites in the U.S. Those sites are in Los Angeles harbor, near the saltponds of southern San Diego Bay, and at Bolsa Chica Ecological Reserve (Hendricks, 2010). Nevertheless, the species is often found from mid-summer to autumn along the coast as far north as Point Reyes (Shuford et al., 1989), with vagrants occasionally north to Washington and British Columbia (Burness et al., 1999). Nest sites include sand-fill and gypsum dikes separating saltponds (Ohlendorf et al., 1985; Schaffner, 1986; Connell, 2007), tidal marshes and mudflats (Monroe, 1956; see also: Collins et al., 1991), and bare sand (Collins and Taylor, 2008; see also: Collins et al., 1991).

Elegant terns forage in open water, both in shallow, nearshore waters such as bays, estuaries, and harbors (Shuford et al., 1989; Connell, 2007) and in the open ocean (Ohlendorf et al., 1985; Connell, 2007; Horn et al., 2009; Hendricks, 2010). Also, Ohlendorf et al. (1985) observed individuals bathing and preening but not feeding in a shallow, brackish estuary.
